title: Heartbleed: The OpenSSL Vulnerability
summary: How a single buffer over-read in OpenSSL exposed private keys for half the internet.
content:
Case Study: Heartbleed

In 2014, security researchers disclosed Heartbleed — a critical vulnerability in OpenSSL that allowed attackers to read up to 64KB of server memory per request, potentially exposing private keys, passwords, and session tokens.

The Bug

The Heartbeat extension in TLS/DTLS failed to validate the length of a request. An attacker could request a response much larger than the sent payload, causing the server to return adjacent memory contents.

Impact

An estimated 17% of the internet's secure servers were vulnerable. Major companies including Yahoo, LastPass, and many cloud providers were affected. Mass certificate revocation and reissuance followed.

Key Learnings

Input validation is non-negotiable. Security audits of critical dependencies are essential. Developers must treat third-party libraries as potential attack surfaces.
